content.description:
Right next door to Thin, Very Thin is just that - very thin in respect to hands and feet. Here reading the rock and balance are key. There are holds here but you gotta look closely and be able and willing to plant and trust your feet. Many climbers rely too much on their hands and on their upper body strength. Listen, your legs are way stronger and your climbing shoes contact the rock on a molecular level! I preach feet - find good feet and your hands will thank you!

 Very Thin is a short but fun route that is another Donation classic. Give it a go and mind your feet. :)
content.protection: Anchor on top of The Buttress. Wide-set glue-ins.

content.description:
This is where most newbies cut their climbing teeth and a route that’s been around since those high-cut gym shorts and tube sock wearing 70’s. An all time Donation classic! Thin offers you TR (top rope) as well as Trad (traditional). It’s a sweet little thin line up Africa Wall that you gotta do and will enjoy.

 Start it wherever you like - some approaches are easier than others so test yourself and try a harder start each time. Anchors for this are on top of The Buttress and are the wide-set glue-ins to your left when on top. You will need two double length slings or a standard cordelette to make it out over the edge with your biners.

I put this route together because I wanted to make something that featured the other side of the giant pointed roof above The Flake. I discovered the left side a few years ago while working its length and up the arête - similar to Barber’s Roof. There’s a huge pocket that I could put both my hands into as I moved out to the point. It was only later when I was setting up for another climb did I look over and see that it looked like an eye and that roof could be the head of a whale. The climb as a whole is pretty killer taking into account the Africa Wall part which is sparse to begin with and the traverse out and up the whale head arête. Hence the name Killer Whale.

 Your start may vary but I like to tackle the little overhanging wall at the bottom vs. the easier approach to the ledge below Africa. Once there stay on the far right of Africa Wall. Top out there and proceed up to the whale head. Move your hands out and into the eye while anchoring your feet below. With your right hand, reach out and grab the nose. Break your feet loose, find new feet, and dead point up higher with your right. Once locked in high, pull up, get your left foot in the eye and stand up. Now up and over. Just like that.
content.protection: TR for now. Same anchors as The Flake but must be placed over the right side edge or redirected.

content.description: It’s called Africa because it’s right side resembles the west coast of the continent. That actual wall sits back a bit and has a big platform/deck at it’s base. Getting to the deck is easy to moderate and that’s where the fun starts! The main route at Africa is called Thin - it’s a semi-crack line in the middle that’s good for a beginner. To the left is a route which is a lay back up the “coastline” to the anchor. To the right of Thin is Very Thin, a crimpy balanced send to the same anchor point which is atop the big prowl to the left of Africa. To the right of Very Thin is Killer Whale that runs just left of the corner and then continues and engages the prominent roof and arête above to a top rope anchor on a level above that - the same anchor that services The Flake.
